Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing in my ears as she explained how important it was for me to lead the family ceremony this year. “It’s your turn,” she said, her eyes shining with pride and expectation. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of them—preserving our traditions, honoring our ancestors. But as I nodded, my phone buzzed with a message from Ahmed, a community member. “Imam, if you have a moment this weekend, I’d really appreciate some advice,” he wrote. I could sense the weight behind his casual words; he rarely reached out, and I knew he must be struggling.

My heart twisted. As a child, I wanted to make my family proud, to be the link that kept our traditions alive. As an imam, I felt the responsibility to be there for my community, to offer guidance when it was needed most. Both roles pulled at me, each demanding my presence, my time, my heart. I stared at the calendar, feeling the pressure build, torn between the expectations of my family and the needs of my community, unsure how I could possibly fulfill both.
